context: About <a0_0>98%<a0_0/> of Antarctica is covered by <b5_0>the <b6_0><b7_0><b8_0><b10_0><b11_0>Antarctic<b8_0/><b7_0/> ice sheet<b11_0/><b10_0/><b6_0/><b5_0/>, a sheet of ice averaging at least <a1_0>1.6 km<a1_0/> (1.0 mi) thick. The continent has about <a2_0>90%<a2_0/> of the <b12_0>world's ice<b12_0/> (and thereby about <a3_0><b13_0>70%<b13_0/><a3_0/> of the world's fresh water). <b14_0>If all of this ice were melted<b14_0/>, sea levels would rise about 60 m (200 ft). In most of <b9_0>the interior<b9_0/> of the continent, precipitation is very low, down to <a4_0>20 mm<a4_0/> (0.8 in) per year; in a few "blue ice" areas precipitation is lower than mass loss by sublimation and so the local mass balance is negative. In the dry valleys, the same effect occurs over a rock base, leading to a desiccated landscape.
